captions.text:
Yeah, right there.
I'm in the cab, man. I'm stuck.

Hey, look. I got to
get out of here.

But he's in this building
doing wild shit.

I need to get out.
You all tied up in there?

Get me out so we
can call the cops.
Give me your wallet.

Are you kidding me?
Do I look like
I'm kidding you?

Don't you see that my hands are
tied to the steering wheel?

I don't care
what they're tied to.

I'll fuck you up.
Don't shoot.

What the fuck else you got
in here? Ooh, jackpot.

Yeah, it is.
Why, you want it back?
What else you got for me? Huh?

title: Collateral (4/9) Movie CLIP - That My Briefcase? (2004) HD

really great enough to factor in.﻿

comments.author: Anthony Pio

comments.text:
This is very true. Personally I believe this is Cruise's finest role to 
date. This should have netted him the Oscar. Collateral has been the only 
film so far, where I've gone to the cinema twice in the same week to see 
it! His role-prep for getting into the mind of "Vincent" was impressive. 
The pistol training was done under the guidance of former Special Air 
Service soldier Michael Gould, and it shows here. Collateral is a movie 
which drips with cool. This scene is classic. The first two guys quickly 
looked at Max's hands tied to the wheel, realised something wasn't right 
and walked on. The second two guys getting up in Vincent's face, thinking 
he was an easy mug...not realising they're trying to screw with a contract 
killer. "What else you got for me...huh?" A swift knockdown into the 
afterlife from a H&K USP! Michael Mann even detailed the sound of Vincent's 
empty brass bouncing off the concrete. Sweet.
comments.author: Fenner1976

comments.text:
+sweetness583 Funniest shit I've read today! "Yo... homie... is that my 
Oscar?" AHAHBBWBBHAHHAH! You're a genius!

Cruise with my hands in the air.

comments.author: JACCO20082012

comments.text:
+Dragunov38 That's Michael Mann's specialty: he ensures he's got the best 
advisers on how guns work and are used in real life for his works. If I 
remember right, he's gotten training at Gunsite and usually has Gunsite 
Alumni and similarly trained people on hand to ensure he's getting the 
gunplay right.
comments.author: RaderizDorret

comments.text:
+Kevin Yamagata Never carry without a holster. One: the gun shifts around 
making it hard to get a consistent draw. Two: it's a good way to shoot 
yourself (ask Plaxico Burress). Three: a well-made holster (think Desantis 
or Galco) will enable a consistent draw. Vincent uses a typical IWB (inside 
the waistband) holster for that USP45 and it enabled him to know where his 
gun was and draw very quickly (which takes practice but is more than 
doable).

As an aside, this clip shows how action beats reaction. The thugs thought 
they were bad and were caught completely off guard. This is why I prefer 
concealment to open carry: I don't intend to let bad guys know I'm packing 
heat until after I've shot them (though I very much prefer not having to 
draw in the first place).
comments.author: RaderizDorret

comments.text:
Youre right but drawing your weapon in practice and drawing it when someone 
is shooting  are two different things. If you don't train a lot you will 
fumble when you need it. The first shot scrambles your brain, it is

fumbled his draw in a real gun fight.
comments.author: David Pickney

comments.text:
Cannot forget this is a Hollywood scenario. However lets consider a couple 
of things.. #1 Vincent is an a Highly trained hit-man, (Ex navy-seal,Delta 
Force, etc..what ever you call it, he could be Spetsnaz) These people are 
trained perform under stress and time constraints. AKA not to flinch. 
Vincent displays all the proper block, stance and firing techniques #2 
these thugs like many of us may have experience firing and knowledge of 
their firearm. but that does not mean that the second suspect was ready for 
the prey to become the hunter. As soon as that first shot was fired by 
Vincent. On an alley were the gun blast sound would be amplified, it would 
make any untrained person flinch AKA my gun is stuck in my waist/pants. I 
say for a Hollywood scenario its pretty real.
comments.author: Dragunov38

comments.text:
+Kevin Yamagata There's no reason to ever carry a handgun without a 
holster. It's far too easy for the trigger to get caught on something and 
set the gun off. That being said, I've seen people carry a gun in a small 
holster in their pants like that, but just putting a loaded handgun in your 
pants without regard is never a good idea.
comments.author: JACCO20082012

comments.author: Kevin Yamagata

comments.text:
I think part of his gun getting "stuck" was on the thug himself. Look how 
cocky and confident he looked when he and the lead guy were approaching 
Vincent, never suspecting that he had a gun, too. Vincent caught him 
completely by surprise, so it was his panic and the surprise disadvantage 
that really did him in. Vincent probably knew the guy would panic, too, 
assessing the situation in those few seconds he had to brainstorm on how he 
would take these 2 lowlifes out.

since it's a movie) so he just plain got lucky with the second guy. 
Though again, it's fucking awesome no matter how you shake it.

comments.author: frank white

comments.text:
Foxx came out of nowhere and never really did anything like this before. 
Plus, I think all the hype for "Ray" helped Foxx score a nomination for 
Supporting Actor for "Collateral". Foxx was very good in "Collateral", but 
I agree with you, Cruise was PERFECT. In reality, Cruise should have been 
the one to get nominated for "Collateral". I've seen other comments here 
that say Cruise looks like he's trying to stay in character. Not in this 
movie! Cruise IS Vincent here. It may not be true of some of his other 
roles, but in "Collateral", he BECOMES the character, and those are the 
performances that should get Oscar recognition. I love this film, but at 
times, with Foxx, I can totally tell he's acting and trying to keep with 
the character. he has his moments, but Cruise never had a moment where he 
wasn't Vincent.

comments.text:
+HarpoTheVillain
Correlation does not mean causation. In Michigan, increased divorce rates 
linked almost exactly with increased consumption of margarine. That doesn't 
mean that one caused the other. You also live in a country that does not 
have an out of control gang violence problem, sharing a border with Mexico, 
an extraordinarily violent country with out of control drug cartels.
comments.author: Pegasi

comments.text:
+HarpoTheVillain
You're basically implying that all who carry are paranoid schizophrenics, 
which is demonstrably false. Why take a chance especially in bad areas? Not 
everyone can have a limousine liberal lifestyle and live in safe, gated 
communities. Are the CCers in Detroit paranoid schizophrenics? Dumb 
generalizations, the source of silly political comments...
comments.author: Pegasi

comments.text:
+David Pickney
'Hoplophobia'? Most of us non-carriers are just people happily liberated 
from the irrational paranoia that 'BAD PEOPLE ARE OUT TO GET ME'.

What was that about promoting stereotypes again? I love weapons and am 
fascinated by the proper firearm handling techniques, I just absolutely do 
not believe that more guns in the open is a good thing. Then again, I live 
in a culture with far lower crime rates (and much, much stricter gun laws) 
than the US.

comments.author: AnarchyEqualityPeace

comments.text:
+James Young If capitalism is the "freedom of choice" then why is Communist 
china OK with it. It's a rhetorical question. Capitalism is the enabler of 
communism, and the 2008 crash and subsequent bailouts destroyed the fiction 
that was capitalism. The truth is the USA was not founded on this fraud 
called capitalism; America  was founded on free markets and 
entrepreneurship. Neither communism or capitalism likes free markets and 
entrepreneurship, if they did monopolies past and present would not exist. 
Capitalism requires an ever increasing ROI and "growth of the economy" 
(tied to the credit/debt system) to sustain itself, as wealth is 
concentrated at the top, and capital winds up preceding labor. That is also 
why companies cannot innovate and CEOs amass tremendous wealth for FAILURE. 
That is called oligarchy, same as Communism;) Eventually, the "quest for 
greed and profit" system becomes so out of control that the sheep clamor 
for socialism, and or, communism to save them from the smoldering mess that 
Capitalism creates. Put it all together.
comments.author: ThePatriotMuckraker

comments.text:
+ThePatriotMuckraker I'm not an anarchist anymore. I was before I began 
taking political science courses. I know, I gotta change it. 1. you can't 
have something that is both communist and capitalist. That is ridiculous. 
2. Communism in it's purest form is a classless and stateless society in 
which all means of production are owned by the community. I think you 
confuse communism and socialism. If you think the US is socialist you are 
wrong. For it to be socialist the government needs to own are regulate all 
means of production. Which, in the US, it doesn't. Now, that doesn't mean 
the US is 100% capitalist. You know what is? Mexico. You can see how well 
that's going for them. The US is and always has been teetering between 
socialist and capitalist. It will still always be capitalist because of the 
way we see economics in the US. Right now it is teetering closer to the 
socialist side then most other times (except probably the new deal) But 
this tends to happens when we have democrats in office. I am a socialist. 
But I don't think it should be forced world wide. I do not believe the US 
can ever become socialist because with our current political system, Fabian 
socialism can not be reached. Now. Explain why I'm wrong. GO!
comments.author: AnarchyEqualityPeace

comments.text:
+ThePatriotMuckraker Just pointing out, don't confused Capitalism with 
Corporatism. One is dependent upon freedom of choice, the other leads to 
the same type of control you see in socialistic countries.
comments.author: James Young
